metadata.description: Advanced and rare English grammar terminology for translation quality assessment

indefinite_article.rule: Use 'an' before vowel sounds, 'a' before consonant sounds

zero_article.definition: Absence of article with specific noun types

phrasal_verb.definition: Verb combined with particle(s) creating idiomatic meaning

types.transitive_separable: Can separate verb and particle (turn off the light / turn the light off)
types.transitive_inseparable: Cannot separate (look after children *NOT* look children after)

modal_verb.definition: Auxiliary verbs expressing necessity, possibility, permission, ability

subjunctive_mood.definition: Verb form expressing hypothetical, wished, or contrary-to-fact situations

forms.present_subjunctive: that he be (not 'is'), that they arrive (not 'arrives')

examples: I suggest that he be present

aspect.definition: Grammatical category expressing temporal flow of action

types.perfect: Completed action with present relevance (She has worked)
types.perfect_progressive: Ongoing action with duration (She has been working)

cleft_sentence.definition: Sentence split into two clauses for emphasis

types.it_cleft: It was John who broke the window

inversion.definition: Non-standard word order placing verb before subject
examples: Never have I seen such beauty
Had I known, I would have come

ellipsis.definition: Omission of words that can be understood from context
examples: I can swim faster than you [can swim]
She likes coffee but I don't [like coffee]

extraposition.definition: Moving a clause to end of sentence, using placeholder 'it'
examples: It is important that we attend (vs. That we attend is important)

head_noun.definition: Core noun in noun phrase that other modifiers describe
head_noun.example: The [very old] book [on the table] [that I bought]

appositive.definition: Noun phrase that renames or explains another noun
examples: My brother, a doctor, lives in Paris

gerund.definition: Verb form ending in -ing used as a noun
gerund.vs_participle: Gerund is noun, participle is adjective/verb form

partitive.definition: Expression indicating part of a whole
partitive.agreement: Verb agrees with 'of' phrase: 'One of the books is...' / 'Some of the books are...'

types.defining_restrictive: Essential to meaning, no commas (The book that I read was good)
types.non_defining_non_restrictive: Additional info, with commas (My car, which is red, is fast)

examples: Whether we go depends on weather

adverbial_clause.definition: Clause functioning as adverb, expressing time, place, reason, etc.

types.time: when, while, before, after, since, until

dummy_subject.definition: Placeholder subject 'it' or 'there' with no semantic meaning
dummy_subject.translation_issue: Some languages don't require dummy subjects

cataphora.definition: Reference forward to something mentioned later
cataphora.example: Before he left, John called his mother ('he' refers forward to 'John')

antecedent.definition: Word or phrase that a pronoun refers to
antecedent.example: John lost his wallet ('John' is antecedent of 'his')

types.subject_verb: The dog runs / The dogs run
types.pronoun_antecedent: Each student must bring his or her book

passive.example: The mouse was caught by the cat

mood.subjunctive: Hypothetical or contrary-to-fact (rare in modern English)

countable_vs_uncountable.definition: Distinction affecting article use, quantifiers, and verb agreement

dual_usage.translation_trap: Some languages differ (e.g., 'information' is countable in some languages)

false_friends_grammar.definition: Grammatical structures that look similar across languages but function differently

examples.present_perfect: English requires 'have been' for continuing states, some languages use present tense
examples.articles: Article usage varies drastically across languages
examples.word_order: English SVO may correspond to different orders in other languages

preposition_usage.no_logic: Preposition choice is often arbitrary and must be memorized

cohesion.definition: Grammatical and lexical linking within text

coherence.definition: Logical and semantic connection between ideas
coherence.vs_cohesion: Cohesion is surface structure, coherence is deep meaning
coherence.requires: Shared knowledge, logical relationships, appropriate organization

information_structure.given_new: Given information first, new information later
information_structure.topic_comment: Topic (what the sentence is about) + Comment (what is said about topic)
information_structure.translation_impact: Information flow may differ across languages
